The paper "LayoutMask: A Novel Pre-trained Model for Visually-rich Document Understanding" proposes a novel pre-trained model, LayoutMask, to address reading order issues in existing document pre-training models. Unlike previous studies that use ascending numbers to represent the global reading order of tokens in a document, LayoutMask uses in-segment token orders as 1D position, referred to as "local 1D position." This allows the model to infer global reading order by jointly using 1D position, 2D position, and semantic information, promoting in-depth text-layout interactions. To further enhance these interactions, the authors equip the Masked Language Modeling task with two novel masking strategies: Whole Word Masking and Layout-Aware Masking. Additionally, a new pre-training objective, Masked Position Modeling, is designed to recover randomly masked 2D positions during pre-training. The joint learning process with both semantic and spatial inference promotes text-layout interactions and helps the model learn better layout representations. Experimental results show that using local 1D position outperforms global 1D position on both FUNSD and SROIE datasets, demonstrating the effectiveness of LayoutMask in addressing reading order issues.

Jiaan presents a joint work, "Towards Unifying Multi-Lingual and Cross-Lingual Summarization," which aims to unify multilingual and cross-lingual summarization into a more general setting called many-to-many summarization. This approach enables a single summarization model to process documents in any source language and generate summaries in any target language. The researchers conducted preliminary studies to analyze the differences between multilingual summarization, cross-lingual summarization, and many-to-many summarization. They found that many-to-many summarization facilitates better task knowledge transfer across languages. To achieve this, the team proposed PISCES, a pre-trained many-to-many summarization model that learns language modeling, cross-lingual ability, and summarization ability through a three-stage pre-training process. Experimental results on the WikiLingua dataset showed that the proposed model outperformed various baselines, including mBART-50 and mT5. Ablation studies and human evaluations further validated the effectiveness of PISCES. This work contributes to the development of more efficient and effective summarization models that can handle multiple languages. The proposed many-to-many summarization setting and the pre-trained model PISCES have the potential to improve language understanding and summarization tasks in real-world applications.

The novelty of the proposed human evaluation method, ABC-Eval, is that it attempts to reduce subjectivity by explicitly annotating whether each model response expresses certain behaviors, rather than relying on human judges to evaluate multiple dimensions of dialogue quality using comparative or Likert scale methods.
The success of the existing weakly supervised approach heavily relies on the availability of an additional clean validation set, which is often overlooked.

To improve the score, the following advances can be done:
1. Developing models that can retrieve partially overlapping background knowledge. 2. Enhancing the model's ability to understand indirect referring expressions. 3. Increasing the model's domain-generalizability. 4. Using more advanced techniques to retrieve background knowledge, such as multi-modal information. 5. Improving the model's ability to disambiguate entities with similar characteristics.

Researchers from AI2 and several other institutions presented a study on the humor understanding capabilities of large language models. They created a dataset using The New Yorker Caption Contest, where readers submit captions for cartoon images, and operationalized it into three tasks: matching, quality ranking, and explanation generation. The study aimed to evaluate the performance of language models on these tasks and compare it to human performance. The results showed that even the best-performing model, CLIP fine-tuned on the corpus, achieved only 62% accuracy on the matching task, compared to 94% for humans. When conditioned to do the same tasks with a human-authored description of the image, language models like GPT-4 still showed a significant performance gap. In the explanation generation task, human explanations were preferred to five-shot GPT-4 explanations in over two-thirds of cases. The study suggests that while large language models can generate jokes and explanations, they do not truly understand humor. The dataset and models are available for further research and experimentation, with a leaderboard to track progress. The findings have implications for the development of more advanced language models that can better understand and generate humor.
Four authors are involved in the paper: Xiaoyu Shen, Marius Mosbach, Andreas Stephan, and Dietrich Klakow, in addition to the speaker Dawei.

This presentation discusses the analysis and improvement of adaptive inference in low-resource settings, specifically focusing on the methods of Multi Model and Early Exit. The authors, Daniel Rotem and colleagues, highlight the pros and cons of each method, noting that Multi Model is more versatile but suffers from high storage costs and overhead, while Early Exit is memory-efficient but prone to conflicting gradients, which can degrade performance. To test their hypothesis, they compared individual Early Exit models to separate Multi Model classifiers, finding that the latter outperformed the former by an average of 2.3%. To address the conflicting gradient issue, the authors propose the SWEET method, which separates weights in Early Exit transformers, allowing each layer to receive updates only from the following classifier. The results show that SWEET closes the gap between Early Exit and Multi Model, outperforming both methods in fast speeds and the entire speed/accuracy curve for BERT-Large. The study's findings motivate future research into fine-tuning algorithms tailored to the Early Exit architecture, and the paper is available on Archive under the title "Finding the SWEET spot".
Three authors are involved in the paper: Matthias Lindemann, Alexander Koller, and Ivan Titov.
Bible texts are simplified more than news texts and language learner texts.

This PhD research proposes a novel method for multimodal relation extraction, addressing two primary issues: internal-information over-utilization and external-information under-exploitation. The existing multimodal relation extraction methods often rely solely on text data, which may lack sufficient context for ambiguous or multi-context words. The proposed method, named GENE-LAMO, incorporates visual sources to enhance the understanding of semantic relations between entities. A Graph Information Bottleneck principle-guided feature refinement is introduced to prune unnecessary information from both text and visual modalities. Additionally, multimodal topic information is leveraged to enrich the overall context. The framework consists of five components: visual scene graph representation, textual scene graph representation, merging the two into a unified backbone cross-modal graph (CMG), fine-grained filtering and adjustment of CMG, and enrichment of CMG features with multimodal topic features. Experimental results on a widely used MRE dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of GENE-LAMO, outperforming text-based methods and multimodal baselines. Ablation studies confirm the importance of internal-information screening and external-information exploiting, which are found to be beneficial in different circumstances, depending on the text-vision relevance of the input.

This presentation discusses the challenges of open-domain question answering systems, particularly in terms of memory costs, inference speed, and performance. The two-stage model proposed by Danqi Chen in 2017, which involves retrieval and reader stages, is a mainstream framework but faces limitations due to the large size of the Wikipedia corpus and the index file. The presentation highlights the need for efficient open-domain question answering systems that can achieve smaller memory costs, faster inference, and comparable performance.
To address these challenges, the authors propose several efficient tactics, including approximate nearest neighbor search for fast evidence research, skip reading for fast reading, and techniques for reducing index size and model size. They also compare existing open-domain question answering models from the data aspect, highlighting the trade-offs between speed, memory, and performance.
Based on this analysis, the authors provide conclusions and insights on how to design efficient open-domain question answering systems, including reducing index size, model size, and pursuing real-time feedback. Finally, they discuss two future works: deploying open-domain question answering systems on low-power devices and considering more evaluation metrics.

Researchers investigated the ability of text-to-image models to render visual text, focusing on the Imagen model and its text encoder, T5. They discovered that T5 models struggle with spelling, particularly for less frequent words, due to the subword tokenization method used. In contrast, PaLM models, which use a different tokenization method, achieve near-perfect spelling accuracy but are impractical due to their large size. ByT5, a model that receives individual bytes of the input string, demonstrated excellent spelling abilities. The researchers found that the frequency of the word being spelled affects T5's performance, with more frequent words being represented by a single vocabulary item, making it harder to decompose into individual letters. To improve text rendering models, they augmented the Imagen model with a ByT5 small model, which significantly improved spelling accuracy and image generation characteristics. The study introduced two new benchmarks, WikiSpell and DrawText, to evaluate text-only and text-to-image models, respectively. The findings suggest that concatenating a character-aware model, like ByT5, to the existing text encoder can efficiently improve model spelling ability, paving the way for better text rendering models.

The experiments were designed to study the effect of the governor's position by analyzing the length of conjuncts in coordination structures in the Penn Treebank. The researchers measured the length of conjuncts in three different scenarios:
1. When the governor is on the left. 2. When the governor is on the right. 3. When there is no governor (e.g., coordination of sentences).
They compared the length of the first conjunct to the second conjunct in each scenario to see if the tendency for the first conjunct to be shorter was affected by the governor's position.

This paper proposes a simple yet effective ensemble learning framework called LLM-Blender for large language models. The key idea is based on pairwise ranking and generative fusion. The framework, developed by a team from AI2 and USC, aims to address the issue of selecting the optimal model for a particular input example. The authors argue that a single top-performing model may not be the best choice for every input, and that ensemble learning can lead to better results. The LLM-Blender framework consists of two stages: a pairwise ranking module called PairRanker, which compares the outputs of multiple models and ranks them based on their quality, and a generative fusion model, GenFuser, which takes the top-ranked models and generates a final output. The PairRanker module uses a cross-attention mechanism to compare pairs of models and learns to distinguish between them. The authors evaluate their framework on a new dataset called MixInstruct, which consists of instruction datasets and candidates from 11 open-source large language models. The results show that the LLM-Blender framework significantly outperforms individual models, including top-performing models like Open Assistant and Vicuna, on various metrics. The authors conclude that LLM-Blender is a promising framework for ensemble learning and release a unified codebase for evaluation and future research.
The affiliations of the authors are not explicitly mentioned in the provided content.
The framework NLPositionality quantifies positionality by comparing annotations from diverse annotators with existing datasets and models using a Pearson's R correlation score.

This presentation introduces CREST, a novel joint framework for rationalization and counterfactual text generation. It combines selective rationalization and counterfactual generation to produce valid, fluent, and diverse counterfactuals in a controllable way. The framework consists of two components: a rationalizer model that generates a meaningful rationale, and an editor that generates counterfactuals by editing specific parts of the input. The quality of the counterfactuals is evaluated through human evaluation and automatic metrics, showing that CREST produces more valid and natural counterfactuals compared to other approaches.
Furthermore, the presentation explores the potential of CREST counterfactuals for data augmentation and proposes an alternative approach, CREST-Rationalization, which leverages paired factual and counterfactual examples to improve downstream models. The results show that CREST-Rationalization achieves top results on in-domain and out-of-domain datasets. Additionally, the analysis of the rationales generated by CREST reveals that they are more plausible and have higher counterfactual simulability compared to other approaches. Overall, CREST offers a new perspective on counterfactual text generation and rationalization, providing a valuable tool for understanding and improving the decision-making processes of machine learning models.

The paper "Learning Language-Specific Layers for Multilingual Machine Translation" proposes a novel approach to increase the capacity of multilingual machine translation models while keeping inference costs constant. The authors introduce Language-Specific Layers (LSLs), which are regular transformer layers per language that can be selectively used at inference time based on the source or target language. This approach allows for more efficient use of model capacity, particularly for low-resource languages. The authors also explore the placement of LSLs within the encoder and propose a method to learn the optimal placement from a large model trained with all possible LSL configurations. The results show that the learned architecture outperforms baseline models and language adapters, with significant improvements for low-resource languages. The improvements are also statistically significant for 84 out of 90 translation directions. The paper presents a novel solution to the trade-off between model capacity and inference efficiency in multilingual machine translation, offering a promising direction for future research in this area. The approach has the potential to improve the performance of machine translation systems for a wide range of languages.

Researchers from the Natural Language Processing Lab at EPFL University and Sony Group Corporation have developed a large-scale Persona Commonsense Knowledge Graph (PeaCoK) to represent real-world personas with rich world knowledge and complex interconnections. PeaCoK contains over 3,800 personas, 40,000 attributes, and 100,000 personal inferences, with 9,200 attributes connected to two or more personas. The graph is built by selecting personas from existing commonsense graphs, inducing attributes from knowledge graphs and pre-trained language models, and crowdsourcing relation annotations. Expert study shows that PeaCoK's accuracy in F1 is 87% using a joint human-AI majority voting scheme. The researchers use PeaCoK to train a BART-based common knowledge generator, achieving better results than large-scale pre-trained language models on persona attribute inference tasks. They also explore using PeaCoK to improve downstream narrative modeling, such as dialogue generation, and find that it yields more consistent and engaging conversations. The study demonstrates that PeaCoK can serve as a reliable persona knowledge base, enabling lightweight language models to learn knowledge generation capabilities comparable to large-scale language models. The paper and GitHub site are publicly available.

A new corpus for German text identification, called DEPLAIN, was introduced to improve text comprehension for specific target groups, such as people with reading problems or non-native speakers. The corpus consists of two subcorpora: DEPLAIN-apa, based on news texts with 13,000 parallel sentence pairs, and DEPLAIN-web, covering various domains with 30,450 sentence pairs. The corpus was created to address issues with existing corpora, which were either too small or relied on automatic alignment methods that can be error-prone.
The DEPLAIN corpus was used to evaluate automatic alignment methods and fine-tune language models for automatic text simplification. The best automatic alignment method for German text simplification was found to be MASSalign. Additionally, fine-tuning language models was shown to produce simplified text with better scores than baseline models. The results were proposed as a base benchmark for the problem of automatic text simplification. The DEPLAIN corpus is a valuable resource for researchers and developers working on text simplification tasks, providing a large and manually aligned dataset for training and evaluating models.
The dataset covers three different domains: music, books, and recipes.

Cognitive dissonance, a phenomenon where two conflicting beliefs or actions exist, is a common occurrence in daily decision-making but rarely expressed in language. Studying dissonance can provide insights into disagreement, attitude changes, and mental health, particularly in understanding extremism and polarization. However, annotating dissonance relations is challenging due to their rarity.
This paper presents a long paper accepted into ACL 2023, "Transfer Learning for Dissonance Detection: Addressing the Rare-Class Challenge." The authors developed a cognitive dissonance resource through large-scale annotation and employed a dissonance-first approach. The initial classifier performed poorly due to the low occurrence of dissonance. To alleviate this, the authors experimented with combinations of transfer learning and active learning to annotate more dissonant samples efficiently.
The study found that transferring weights from closely related tasks, such as topic-independent dissonance stance classification and binary classification of expansion and comparison classes, significantly improved zero-shot performance. The authors also determined the best method to update a model with new data from each round of active learning, finding that "Cumulative" performed better than "Iterative" across the board. A proposed Probability-of-Rare-Class strategy was found to be effective in selecting examples likely to be dissonant, resulting in improved dissonance classification AUC to 0.75.

This study presents DrBERT, a robust pre-trained model in French for biomedical and clinical domains. DrBERT is based on RoBERTa and trained on NACHOS, a dataset of medical crawled data from the web. The authors compare DrBERT with other models, including ChuBERT, which is based on anonymized clinical data. They also investigate the impact of pre-training strategy and the effect of data size on model performance. The study evaluates seven models on 11 biomedical and clinical downstream tasks in French, including named entity recognition, classification, and question answering. The results show that models perform best on tasks with data of the same nature as their training data, but data from heterogeneous sources appear to be more versatile. The study also finds that using more data leads to better performance, and from-scratch pre-training obtains higher performance on most tasks. The authors conclude that DrBERT outperforms the generic model, CamemBERT, on nine out of 11 downstream tasks. The pre-trained models and training scripts are freely available on Hugging Face and GitHub, respectively. This study contributes to the development of specialized language models for French biomedical and clinical domains, addressing the lack of open-source models in these areas.

This paper presents a systematic study of knowledge distillation for natural language generation (NLG) tasks, aiming to compress large language models while preserving their performance. The authors explore various NLG tasks, including summarization, question generation, common sense reasoning, and simplification and style transfer, using a medium-resource labeled dataset and large amounts of unlabeled data. They consider industry-driven setups, prioritizing inference time efficiency and practicality.
The study consists of eight stages, focusing on architectural decisions, pruning, knowledge selection, and state-of-the-art baselines. The main contribution lies in the exploration of pseudo-targets, challenging traditional sequence-level knowledge distillation. The authors demonstrate the importance of unlabeled data, generating multiple pseudo-targets, and sampling pseudo-targets with high temperature to expose the student to more diverse knowledge. They also propose a novel knowledge distillation technique, joint-teaching, which addresses student exposure bias and grounded learning. Joint-teaching applies word-level knowledge distillation on pseudo-targets generated by both the teacher and the student. The study provides a comprehensive analysis of knowledge distillation for NLG tasks, offering a recipe for distillation in NLG.
The metric sensitivity measures a model's ability to consistently produce the same outputs for the same task regardless of slight variations in the wording of the instruction.

This paper surveys the development of deep learning methods for mathematical reasoning, a fundamental aspect of human intelligence. Recent years have seen a surge of interest in this area, with the task of mathematical reasoning categorized into visual and tabular contexts. The authors discuss the challenges of solving geometric problems and automated theorem proving, highlighting the need for neuro-symbolic reasoning over geometric diagrams, theorems, and solvers. They also explore the use of sequence-to-sequence models, sequence-to-tree models, and pre-trained language models (LLMs) to solve math word problems. However, LLMs face limitations, including the lack of ability to perform precise mathematical reasoning. To address this, the authors propose the use of self-consistency and program-aided LMMs, which can be augmented with various tools to perform complex tasks. The paper also touches on the need for non-English datasets and benchmarks for financial, scientific, and medical domains. Despite progress, language models commonly display generalization and robustness failures on reasoning tasks, particularly with large numbers and inconsistent mathematical reasoning. The authors conclude by highlighting the importance of continued research in this area to develop more robust and generalizable models.

In multilingual translation models, interference can occur when training on multiple languages, leading to decreased performance. This study investigates the factors contributing to interference and synergy in multilingual translation models. The researchers identify model and data size as the primary factors affecting interference levels, with severe interference occurring in parameter poverty settings. They find that language similarity and the number of languages have a limited impact on interference. To mitigate interference, the study proposes temperature sampling as a simple yet effective solution, allowing for more training examples to be sampled from lower-resource languages. The results show that tuned temperature is key for strong performance, and that modest scale and tuned temperature can significantly reduce interference without the need for specialized methods. The study concludes that model and data size are the primary factors affecting interference levels, and that temperature sampling is a crucial factor in achieving strong performance in multilingual translation models. The findings provide valuable insights for improving the performance of multilingual translation models.

This work presents the AltEntities Corpus, a large-scale dataset for resolving indirect referring expressions in conversational systems. The dataset consists of 6,000 alternative questions across three domains: music, books, and recipes, with 42,000 indirect referring expressions. The corpus was collected using a crowd annotation methodology, where annotators were provided with a dialogue context and asked to select one of two entities using an indirect reference. The dataset is designed to capture the nuances of human language when making choices, and to evaluate the ability of language models to understand indirect references. Experiments using the T5 XL model showed that when the model has access to the same background knowledge as the annotators, it achieves high accuracy (92-95%). However, when the model has access to partially overlapping background knowledge, accuracy drops to 82-87%. The results also demonstrate that the models are domain-generalizable. The AltEntities Corpus provides a valuable resource for benchmarking language models' entity understanding and improving conversational systems.

The need to develop new methods for measuring media biases arises from the fact that traditional methods may not be effective in detecting biases in modern media, such as social media and online news sources, which often present diverse and nuanced perspectives.

This paper presents Dense-ATOMIC, a densely-connected commonsense knowledge graph constructed upon the ATOMIC knowledge base. ATOMIC is a large-scale knowledge base covering event-centered social aspects, but its sparse graph structure and limited multi-hop paths hinder its effectiveness. Dense-ATOMIC addresses these limitations by inferring missing links and constructing multi-hop paths. The construction process involves normalizing tail events, training a relation prediction model, and constructing Dense-ATOMIC. A novel relation prediction model, Rel-CSKGC, is proposed to predict relations given head and tail events. Rel-CSKGC utilizes semantic information and avoids graph structure limitations. To efficiently infer missing links, an Intra- and Inter-Cluster Completion Strategy is designed. The performance of Rel-CSKGC is evaluated against relation prediction and translation-based methods, outperforming them on automatic and human evaluation. Dense-ATOMIC is also evaluated, showing improved knowledge coverage and benefiting the performance of COMET. The results demonstrate the potential of Dense-ATOMIC in commonsense reasoning and its advantages in knowledge coverage and multi-hop paths. The paper concludes by providing the code and website for further exploration.

Zheng Yandan presents Jointprop, a joint semi-supervised learning framework for name entity recognition (NER) and relation extraction (RE) tasks. Current studies neglect the interconnections between NER and RE, which can lead to missing label alignment and incorrect pseudo-label inference. Jointprop addresses this issue by fully exploiting the connections among labeled and unlabeled data, and between labeled and unlabeled data. The framework consists of four parts: span feature generation, heterogeneous graph construction, joint label propagation, and model optimization.
In the joint label propagation process, labels are propagated to entity or relation candidates in the unlabeled data through a heterogeneous graph, refining pseudo-labels until convergence. The converged pseudo-labels are then filtered and combined with the label data to retrain the classification model.
Experiments were conducted on four datasets, including joint-task and single-task datasets, and showed that joint learning of the two tasks benefits from the codependency between them in joint datasets. For single-task datasets, Jointprop achieved significant and consistent improvement over all baselines for both NER and RE tasks. Overall, Jointprop provides a novel approach to semi-supervised joint NER and RE, leveraging the connections between the two tasks to improve performance.

The political bias propagation pipeline, as proposed by the researchers, consists of the following stages:
1. Pretraining data: Large-scale web crawl data, including news media, which may contain social biases and political opinions. 2. Language model training: Models are trained on the pretraining data, potentially inheriting the biases and political leanings from the data. 3. Downstream tasks: Trained language models are applied to various tasks, such as hate speech detection and fake news detection, where their biases and leanings can impact performance and fairness.

Researchers from Yale University and Microsoft Research have developed a new dataset, DeFacto, to improve the factual consistency of summarization models. The dataset contains human demonstrations and feedback for improving summarization factual consistency, collected from the XSum dataset. The study proposes three new Natural Language Generation (NLG) tasks: summary editing, feedback generation, and automatic factual error correction.
The team collected 2,500 data points, with 70% containing factual errors. Human-edited summaries received higher automatic factuality scores compared to initial system outputs but showed lower textual overlap with reference summaries. The study found that fine-tuned models and zero-shot large language models can effectively leverage human feedback for summary editing, while feedback generation remains a challenging task.
The researchers also found that the editor model can achieve comparable performance to baseline models in automatically correcting factual errors, and training the model to generate explanations can improve performance. The DeFacto dataset provides a valuable resource for training factuality metrics and factuality meta-evaluation. The dataset has been released on GitHub, and the study's findings are detailed in the paper "On Improving Summarization Factual Consistency from Natural Language Feedback."

This paper proposes a novel framework, Unsupervised Learning from Rank Aggregation (ULRA), for automated essay scoring (AES) without human intervention. Traditional AES models rely on large labeled corpora, but collecting these labels is time-consuming and labor-intensive. ULRA aims to overcome this limitation by aggregating multiple heuristic quality signals as pseudo-groundtruth to train a neural AES model. The proposed framework consists of two main components: a heuristic essay ranking module (HER) and a deep pairwise rank aggregation module (DPRA). HER generates partial-order pairs by ranking essays according to multiple classic quality signals, while DPRA trains a neural AES model by aggregating these pairs into a unified supervision. To address conflicts among different signals, a deep pairwise rank aggregation loss is designed to set learnable confidence weights for each signal. Experimental results on both transductive and inductive settings demonstrate that ULRA outperforms all unsupervised baselines with a large improvement, achieving competitive performance compared to cross-prompt and one-shot methods. Although ULRA's performance is lower than that of general supervised methods due to the lack of strong supervision, it provides a promising solution for unsupervised essay scoring.

Title: PAD-Net: An Efficient Framework for Dynamic Networks
Abstract:
Traditional networks are static, with fixed parameters that cannot change with input values. In contrast, dynamic networks can adapt their architecture or parameters based on the input. However, fully dynamic networks can lead to excessive parameter usage, limiting their application. This paper proposes PAD-Net, a Partially Dynamic Network framework that partitions parameters into dynamic and static components. The framework uses Iterative Mode Partition to identify redundant dynamic parameters, which are then transformed into static parameters. This approach aims to maintain or exceed the representation power of the original network while reducing parameters and computation. Experiments show that PAD-Net outperforms static and dynamic networks, and maintains fewer parameters and less computation compared to fully dynamic networks. Ablation studies reveal the importance of Dynamic Ratios and Scale Factors in achieving optimal performance. Compared to network pruning, PAD-Net demonstrates significantly better performance due to the preservation of static parameters. The proposed framework is also found to produce more discriminative outputs, contributing to its improved performance. Future works include extending PAD-Net to other mainstream networks, exploring hardware-friendly structured manners, and introducing additional modes such as zero elements and static parameters.

This study challenges the conventional notion that native speakers are essential for data annotation in Natural Language Processing (NLP). The authors of "Rethinking Annotation: Can Language Learners Contribute?" conducted a proof-of-concept study to examine the feasibility of using language learners as annotators. They recruited learners of English, Korean, and Indonesian, and native speakers, and had them annotate tasks from the GLUE benchmark. The study found that labels annotated by language learners were nearly accurate, especially for simpler tasks, and that their aggregated labels were almost on par with those of native speakers. Furthermore, training simulations showed that language models trained on learners' less accurate labels achieved about 95% of ground truth performance and sometimes outperformed models trained with native speakers' labels. The study also observed that learners' language proficiency improved as they carried out the annotation tasks. The findings suggest that language learners can contribute to NLP annotations, offering a novel way to build benchmark datasets for low-resource languages where native speakers are hard to recruit. This study has the potential to broaden NLP research and overcome geographic and technological barriers.

This paper proposes a novel backdoor-based watermark method called "Embedding Marker" to protect the copyright of large language models used in embedding as services. Embedding as services is a technique that leverages large language models, such as GPT and LLAMA, to assist various natural language processing (NLP) tasks. However, recent works have shown that attackers can steal the model by learning from the embedding and provide similar services. To address this issue, the Embedding Marker method embeds a watermark in the provider service and detects whether another service contains the watermark. The method consists of two main steps: watermark injection and copyright verification. In watermark injection, a target embedding is defined, and the provided embedding is a weight summation of the target embedding and the original embedding, where the weight is proportional to the number of triggers in the sentence. In copyright verification, a backdoor dataset and a benign dataset are constructed, and the similarities between the requested embedding and the target embedding are computed. The authors conduct experiments on four datasets and demonstrate that the Embedding Marker can achieve great detection performance while maintaining great utility for downstream tasks.
There is no information about the first author of PaLM in the given content.

Three problems of SimulST models are mentioned:
1. Specific architectures are usually trained, introducing additional modules to be optimized. 2. Long and complicated training procedures. 3. Training and maintaining several models to reach different latency regimes.

To mitigate social and political biases in datasets when training NLP models, consider the following strategies:
1. **Diversify datasets**: Include diverse perspectives, sources, and authors to reduce bias from dominant viewpoints. 2. **Data curation**: Carefully select and preprocess data to remove or downweight biased content. 3. **Regular auditing**: Regularly evaluate and update datasets to ensure they remain fair and unbiased. 4. **Data augmentation**: Use techniques like data augmentation, noise injection, or adversarial training to reduce bias. 5. **Model debiasing**: Implement debiasing techniques, such as removing biased tokens or using debiasing word embeddings. 6. **Fairness metrics**: Use fairness metrics to evaluate and compare the performance of biased and unbiased models. 7. **Human evaluation**: Conduct human evaluation to assess the fairness and accuracy of NLP models.

The talk discusses PromptRank, a data-efficient approach for multi-hop question answering (QA) that addresses the issue of requiring thousands of examples for good performance. Existing state-of-the-art multi-hop retrievers are trained by maximizing the probability of ground-truth chains given questions, but this can be expensive and challenging, especially for low-resource domains. PromptRank combines an unsupervised retrieval method with a few-shot language model-based reranker to achieve good performance with as few as 128 examples. The approach involves retrieving candidate chains using TF-IDF retrieval and hyperlink traversal, and then reranking these candidates using a language model reranker. The scoring function used is the likelihood of the question given the chain according to a language model, and the instruction plays a strong role in eliciting the language model's reasoning abilities. The talk presents results showing that PromptRank outperforms fully supervised systems and performs comparably to state-of-the-art multi-hop dense retrievers. The approach also exhibits strong downstream multi-hop QA performance when used as a retriever with a reader model.
Comparable to state-of-the-art systems.

The watermarking method should meet the following properties:
1. Applicable to embedding as services. 2. Not degrade the utility of the provided embeddings. 3. Covert enough to the attacker or the attacker can remove the watermark easily. 4. Transferable to the attacker's services during the model extraction process.

The paper presents the QUEST dataset, a retrieval dataset designed to study the effectiveness of systems handling selective information needs with implicit set constraints. The dataset consists of over 3,000 entity-seeking queries with verified answer entities and attributable spans for query constraints. The queries are constructed by performing set operations over Wikipedia category names from four domains: films, books, plants, and animals. Human annotators paraphrased the queries, validated their fluency, and verified the relevance of answer entities with marked evidence from documents. To evaluate systems, the dataset requires multi-answer sets from a large document corpus with implicit set constraints and evidence from multiple parts of the document. Baseline systems, including sparse and dense retrievers, and a T5-based reranker, demonstrate a large room for improvement in retriever performance and end-to-end system performance. Analysis reveals that queries with set intersection and set difference are particularly challenging. The QUEST dataset aims to help researchers build improved systems for information-seeking scenarios with selective information needs, such as Jane's query for a red reptile species or Austin's search for historical fiction novels set in France.
The multilingual encoder-based models, such as XLM-R + PTR and mBERT + PTR, were used as Encoder-PTR models.

This ACL 2023 paper revisits the minimal pair paradigm (MPP) for evaluating language models on acceptability judgments. The current MPP pipeline is limited to evaluating short sentences, but large language models now operate with longer context windows. To address this, the authors simulate longer sequences by recreating sentences with grammatical or ungrammatical structures from relevant datasets. They test the models' acceptability judgments in various scenarios, including mismatched and unrelated contexts.
The results show that MPP judgments are relatively robust to arbitrary context length, but sensitive to context when the sentences come from the same dataset or have the same structure. The model's acceptability judgments significantly increase or decrease when adding acceptable or unacceptable prefixes, respectively. However, when the prefix structure matches, the effect is massive, increasing throughout the context length.
Analysis of perturbed input sentences reveals that the model's sensitivity to noise is consistent across acceptable and unacceptable domains. The authors conclude that language models are sensitive to latent syntactic and semantic features shared across sentences. The current MPP evaluation may not capture the models' abstract knowledge throughout the context window, highlighting the need for more comprehensive evaluation methods.

This paper introduces Unnatural Instructions, a large dataset of natural language instructions and their corresponding inputs and outputs, collected in a fully automatic manner without human annotations. The dataset was generated by prompting a pre-trained language model to produce instructions, inputs, and outputs, and further diversified through paraphrasing. With over 240,000 examples, Unnatural Instructions contains a diverse range of tasks, including creative and unconventional tasks such as verifying scientific experiment design and inventing new words. The authors analyze the dataset's quality, finding that more than 50% of the generated examples are correct, and even incorrect examples contain valuable information for instruction tuning. To evaluate the utility of the dataset, the authors fine-tune a large T5 model on Unnatural Instructions and show that it outperforms other models on several benchmarks, including Super-Natural Instructions, T0, BIG-Bench Hard, and LMentry. The results demonstrate the potential of language models to produce high-quality data, which can be obtained at a lower cost and faster pace than human annotations. The Unnatural Instructions dataset provides a valuable resource for instruction tuning and natural language processing research.
The authors decide what moderate-frequency words are by collecting a general text corpus and counting the word frequency with it.

Researchers from Nanyang Technological University of Singapore presented their work, "Finding the Pillars of Strength for Multi-Head Attention," at ACL 2023. The study focuses on addressing the limitations of large language models, particularly the heavy parameters, which hinder their deployability and efficiency. The team proposed a grouped head attention mechanism, which utilizes a divide-and-conquer strategy to compress multi-head attention. The model consists of two stages: group-constrained training and the Voting-to-Stay algorithm. The first stage divides attention heads into groups, making intra-group heads more similar and inter-group heads more separate. The second stage prunes redundant heads using a voting system. The proposed model, GHT, achieves significant parameter compression, with up to 90% reduction, while maintaining comparable performance. Evaluation on machine translation, language modeling, and abstractive summarization tasks shows promising results, with 3.8% to 7% BLEU improvement over state-of-the-art baselines. The study also demonstrates the efficiency of the proposed model, with 62% faster inference speed and 80% fewer FLOPs. The researchers believe that task-specific automatic pruning is a promising direction for future work, allowing for the pruning of redundant parameters in large language models without sacrificing performance.
The approach, EDAtt, does not specify a fixed speech segment size. Instead, it uses a variable size, referred to as lambda speech frames, which is determined by the attention mechanism.

This paper presents "Improving Pretraining Techniques for Code-Switched NLP," a submission to the ACL 2023 conference. Code-switching, a common phenomenon in linguistically diverse communities, refers to the practice of alternating between two or more languages within a sentence. The authors highlight the limitations of existing multilingual pre-trained models, such as mBERT and XLM-R, in handling code-switched tasks like question answering and sentiment analysis. To address this, they propose a novel masked language modeling (MLM) technique called SwitchMLM, which is specifically designed to handle code-switching. SwitchMLM identifies "switch-points," or transitions between languages, and masks only these words, rather than all words with uniform probability. The authors also introduce a surrogate method, FrequencyMLM, which uses monolingual corpora to assign language IDs (LIDs) to words. Additionally, they propose architectural modifications, including residual connections and an auxiliary LID-based loss, to enhance the model's ability to capture switch-point information. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of their proposed methods, particularly on sentiment analysis tasks. The paper also presents probing experiments to verify the increased presence of switch-point information in intermediate and final layers. Overall, the authors provide a comprehensive approach to improving pretraining techniques for code-switched NLP.
GPT-4, RoBERTa, and BART series are the language models focused on in the extended experiments.

In this research, Ying and Zhiyang present MultiInstruct, a novel multi-modal instruction tuning benchmark dataset consisting of 62 diverse tasks covering 10 broad categories. This dataset is designed to investigate whether instruction tuning can improve generalization to unseen multi-modal tasks. The authors take OFA, a unified multi-modal pre-trained model, as their base model and formulate tasks in a unified sequence-to-sequence format to unify the processing of various input and output data types.
In their experiments, the authors demonstrate that instruction tuning can significantly improve OFA's performance on seen multi-modal tasks and that transfer learning from natural instruction datasets can benefit instruction tuning. They also introduce a new metric called sensitivity to measure the model's ability to consistently produce the same outputs for the same task regardless of slight variations in instruction wording. The results show that using more instructions can improve the model's overall performance and reduce its sensitivity. Furthermore, transfer learning from natural instruction datasets can help OFA achieve better performance and sensitivity. The authors propose MultiInstruct as the first large-scale multi-modal instruction tuning dataset and explore different transfer learning techniques, showcasing their benefits.

A research study, "Towards Benchmarking and Improving the Temporal Reasoning Capability of Large Language Models," was conducted to comprehensively evaluate the temporal reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs). The study proposed a novel dataset, TempReason, which covers three levels of temporal reasoning: time-to-time, time-to-event, and event-to-event. The dataset consists of over 130,000 question-answer pairs and spans a long temporal coverage. The study evaluated the performance of four LLMs, including ChatGPT, in three question-answering (QA) settings: Closed Book QA, Open Book QA, and Reasoning QA. The results showed that ChatGPT demonstrated a strong bias towards the 2000-2020 time period and struggled with month prediction. To improve temporal reasoning, the study proposed a training strategy with two components: Temporal span extraction pre-training and time-sensitive reinforcement learning. The proposed model, TempT5, significantly outperformed the baseline models in all QA settings, especially in the Reasoning QA setting. The study highlights the importance of comprehensive temporal reasoning and proposes a new benchmark dataset and training paradigm to improve the temporal reasoning capabilities of LLMs.

Researchers Namgyu Ho, Laura Schmid, and Se-Young Yun propose a novel method to enable large language models to solve complex tasks without requiring huge memory and computation. Their technique, called "Large Language Models Are Reasoning Teachers," utilizes large models as "reasoning teachers" to transfer their abilities to smaller models. The method involves applying chain-of-thought prompting on large models to generate step-by-step solutions for complex tasks, which are then used as training data to fine-tune smaller models. A novel technique called "Diverse Reasoning" is also introduced, where multiple reasoning samples are generated using stochastic temperature sampling, allowing smaller models to learn from diverse solutions. The researchers demonstrate the effectiveness of their method on 12 tasks, achieving notable performance and outperforming existing baselines. The method is also shown to be highly scalable, with various ways to improve performance, such as using more datasets, better teacher models, or larger student models. However, trade-offs between development costs, inference costs, and quality of inference must be considered. The researchers provide code and data for their experiments, encouraging future work and discussion.

This presentation discusses a new diagnostic test suite, called KITMUS, for evaluating the ability of natural language understanding models to integrate knowledge from multiple sources. The test suite focuses on coreference resolution, a task that requires models to draw on both pretraining-time knowledge and inference-time knowledge. The authors propose three settings for KITMUS, varying the availability of background knowledge and entity-specific knowledge. They evaluate the test suite with human study participants and established coreference resolution models, and find that most models perform poorly without task-specific training. However, with task-specific training, some models successfully integrate knowledge from multiple sources. The results suggest that even the best-performing models struggle to reliably integrate background knowledge provided only at inference time. The KITMUS test suite and data set are made available on GitHub, providing a valuable resource for researchers to evaluate the ability of natural language understanding models to integrate knowledge from multiple sources. This work highlights the importance of task-specific training for achieving robust performance in knowledge-intensive NLU tasks.

ABC-Eval is a novel dimensional approach to evaluating conversational AI, developed by the Emory NLP Lab in collaboration with Amazon Alexa AI. This method aims to provide a more precise and reliable evaluation of chat models by explicitly annotating specific behaviors, such as irrelevant information, self-contradiction, and common sense violations. ABC-Eval measures the rates at which chat models commit various thematic errors, including ignoring partners, hallucinating incorrect facts, and violating common sense knowledge. The approach was tested on four state-of-the-art chat models, evaluated on 100 human-bot conversations per model, and compared to three existing methods: Likert ratings on the turn-level, Likert ratings on the dialogue-level, and dialogue-level pairwise comparisons. The results show that ABC-Eval behavior labels are more reliable and predictive of overall conversation quality compared to existing methods. The combination of ABC-Eval metrics explains over 25% of conversation quality, highlighting the potential of this approach to evaluate conversational AI with higher resolution. The study also identifies challenges, such as common sense violations and irrelevant information, which future models may address. ABC-Eval is proposed as a meaningful step towards developing reliable and precise evaluation metrics for comparing conversational AI models.

Jasivan presents the work "FERMAT: An Alternative to Accuracy for Numerical Reasoning" conducted with supervisor Nafise at the University of Sheffield. The motivation behind this work is to address the limitations of existing numerical reasoning benchmarks, which often rely on accuracy scores and F1 measures that do not provide insight into the strengths and weaknesses of models. The authors introduce FERMAT, a flexible evaluation set based on arithmetic types, which includes number understanding, mathematical operation, and training dependency aspects. FERMAT consists of maths worded questions extracted from Illinois and CommonCore, with variations in number representation and mathematical operations. The authors perform a baseline evaluation and fine-tuning using math teacher-written templates, which improves model performance. They also investigate the impact of training templates and find that language and mathematical diversity are crucial for improving performance. The study concludes that existing benchmarks are unrepresentative and that FERMAT provides a more informative alternative. The authors highlight the importance of number encoding and tokenization as areas for improvement.

Researchers from the Singapore University of Technology and Design propose a novel machine learning task, language-guided floor plan generation, where a model generates 2D floor plan designs directly from language instructions. The task is defined as a sequence-to-sequence problem under the encoder-decoder framework, where the input is a set of natural language instructions and the output is a structured interior layout that aligns with the input instructions. The team collects a large-scale dataset, Tell2Design, consisting of 5,051 human-annotated language instructions and 76,000 artificially generated instructions.
A sequence-to-sequence model is proposed as a strong baseline, initialized by a pre-trained language model T5, to better understand language instructions. The model outperforms text-conditional image generation baselines by a large margin, achieving a Micro IoU of 54 and a Macro IoU of 53 on the Tell2Design dataset. However, the model performs poorly when trained on artificial instructions and tested on human-written ones, indicating a language distribution gap. The study demonstrates that artificial and human interactions are mutually beneficial data portions during training. The proposed task and dataset provide a foundation for future research on language-guided design generation, enabling users to design by "telling" instructions and enhancing the design process.
The authors claim that the ability to integrate and use both pretrain-time and inference-time knowledge is an understudied area in NLU.

Yicheng, a PhD student from Fudan University, presented a paper on the analysis of omission in dialogue summarization. The study aims to address the common error of omission in dialogue summarization, where critical facts are lost in generated summaries. The analysis revealed that even state-of-the-art models reach a high omission rate of around 70%, indicating a general and serious problem in dialogue summarization. To better understand and solve this issue, the authors developed the OLDS dataset, which provides high-quality omission labels for dialogue summarization. The dataset is built upon five existing benchmarks covering five domains and includes 10 diverse candidate summaries generated by different models and decoding strategies.
The authors explored three baseline frameworks for omission detection, including pair-wise classification, sequence labeling, and pointer network. The results showed a challenging task with an F1-score of around 50%, indicating the need for more advanced detection models. The study also demonstrated the potential of using omissions to refine summaries, with a post-editing method that boosts summary quality when omission is provided. The findings suggest that omission detection is a valuable task, and refinement based on detected omission is a promising direction for quality improvement in dialogue summarization.
Three authors are involved in the paper: Myra, Esin Durmus, and Dan Jurafsky.

Archiki presents the ACL paper "MEETINGQA: Extractive Question-Answering on Meeting Transcripts," which introduces a new dataset for extractive question answering based on meeting transcripts. Meeting transcripts are a vast and underutilized domain for NLP research, offering a unique opportunity for QA models to learn from real-life discussions. The MeetingQA dataset consists of 7.7K questions with corresponding answer sentences, covering various scenarios such as multiple speakers, discontinuous sentences, and rhetorical questions. The dataset is split into Train, Dev, and Test sets, with 30% of questions being unanswerable and 40% having multispan answers. The authors achieve a high human performance on the Test set with an F1 score of 84.6.
The paper explores various methods for QA models, including context-retrieval, single-span, and multi-span models. In the fine-tuned setting, short-context models like RoBERTa outperform long-context models like Longformer. However, there is a significant gap between fine-tuned models and human performance. The authors also investigate zero-shot performance, where silver data augmentation improves results. Error analysis reveals challenges in identifying rhetorical questions, irrelevant sentences, and speaker identification, particularly in the zero-shot setting. MeetingQA is a challenging dataset that pushes the limits of existing QA models, offering opportunities for future research and improvement.

Researchers in the field of classical philology have developed new language models specifically designed to process Ancient Greek and Latin texts. The team aimed to create models that surpass existing state-of-the-art performance, explore different architectures, and introduce multilingual models. They pre-trained two monolingual models, GreBERTa and GreTa, for Ancient Greek, and two multilingual models, PhilBERTa and PhilTa, for Ancient Greek, Latin, and English. The team gathered pre-training data from Open Greek & Latin, additional resources, and a new corpus from the Internet Archive. They leveraged OCR settings and post-processing to create a high-quality pre-training corpus. The models were benchmarked on tasks such as part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing, and lemmatization, and demonstrated significant improvements over existing models. The researchers also analyzed the performance of GreTa's encoder and found that it approaches the performance of a native encoder-only model after more training. The multilingual model showed no significant difference in performance compared to the monolingual models. The new language models are designed to be powerful tools for classical philology, enabling scholars to process and analyze Ancient Greek and Latin texts more efficiently.

This study focuses on resolving ambiguities in text-to-image generative models, which are crucial for faithful image generation. The researchers, from Amazon Alexa AI's Responsible AI team, present a work titled "Resolving Ambiguities in Text-to-Image Generative Models." They propose frameworks to mitigate and evaluate ambiguities in prompts provided to text-to-image models. The study begins by curating a benchmark dataset, a modified version of the LAVA corpus, which covers various types of ambiguities. The dataset is used to develop a prompt disambiguation framework, which gathers external signals to disambiguate the prompt through clarifying questions or generating different possible visual setups. The disambiguated prompts are then evaluated using a VQA model, which assesses whether the generated images are faithful to user intention. The study reveals disparities in resolving ambiguities for different types of ambiguities and shows that disambiguation using the proposed framework has a positive effect on faithful generation. The automatic evaluation framework is also found to be reliable, agreeing with human evaluation. This work aims to improve text-to-image models by addressing ambiguities and providing a reliable evaluation framework.
The University of Trento and Foundazione Bruno Kessler.
Bob.

This presentation introduces a novel dialogue summarization model, "Dialogue Summarization with Static-Dynamic Structure Fusion Graph" (SDDS), developed by a team of researchers from Shandong University. The SDDS model aims to distill the salient information from a dialogue context into a concise summary, addressing the challenges of existing methods that heavily rely on pre-computed static graph structures and external linguistic tools. The proposed model consists of four main components: Utterance Encoder, Static-Dynamic Graph module, and Summary Generator. The Static-Dynamic Graph module combines multiple static graphs computed using heuristic dialogue structure modeling methods, such as Discourse Parsing Graph and Utterance Position Graph, with a dynamic graph module that captures semantic relationships between utterances using multi-head attention. The model also employs a pre-trained language model as the Summary Generator to fuse the static and dynamic dialogue structures into a final summary. The SDDS model is designed to dynamically adapt to the downstream dialogue summarization task, addressing the limitations of existing methods and improving the accuracy of dialogue summarization. The code and data have been released on GitHub for further research and development.

A novel approach to neural coreference resolution, known as "Dual Cache," is proposed to efficiently handle long documents. The task of coreference resolution involves identifying mentions and clustering them into entities that refer to the same entity. Conventional methods have quadratic complexity, while cache-based methods reduce it to a linear level but suffer from high cache misses due to topic switching in long documents. The proposed Dual Cache system consists of a local cache using LRU eviction policy and a global cache using LFU policy. It scans the document from left to right, classifying new mentions and evaluating their frequency. Qualified entities are added to the global cache, while others are added to the local cache. Evaluation on four public benchmarks shows that Dual Cache outperforms baselines, even with unbounded memory, and significantly reduces cache misses. The approach is particularly effective for book-level documents, demonstrating a substantial performance gap between the baseline and Dual Cache. Overall, Dual Cache offers a cost-effective solution to neural coreference resolution, achieving the highest performance/cost ratio among cache-based methods.

The benefit of weakly supervised learning is that it allows for training neural networks using cheaper, noisy annotations, such as simple heuristic rules, knowledge bases, or low-quality crowdsourcing, rather than requiring expensive, high-quality human annotations.

Wenting Zhao, a PhD student at Cornell University, presents a paper titled "Abductive Commonsense Reasoning Exploiting Mutually Exclusive Explanations". Abductive reasoning aims to identify a plausible explanation bridging the information gap between a given context and outcome. Traditional approaches rely on supervised methods, which require annotated explanations and can be noisy and subjective. To address this issue, the authors introduce an unsupervised learning method called LiPoR (Likelihood Learning with Posterior Regularization). LiPoR treats explanations as latent variables and maximizes the marginal likelihood of the outcome given the context. However, this objective alone does not prefer plausible explanations, so a regularizer is added to enforce mutual exclusivity among explanations. The LiPoR objective consists of two parts: maximizing the likelihood of outcomes and preferring some explanations over others. Experimental results on the AlphaNLI dataset show that LiPoR outperforms zero-shot models and the previous best unsupervised approach by over 4 absolute points in accuracy. The authors demonstrate that abductive reasoning can be learned without supervision regarding the plausibility of explanations, opening up new possibilities for this field.

Researchers from Harbin Institute of Technology, Shenzhen, have proposed a novel image retrieval framework addressing the challenge of linguistically complex text descriptions. Inspired by the Divide-and-Conquer strategy and Dual-Process Theory, the proposed method, Neural Divide-and-Conquer Reasoning (NDCR), integrates two thinking systems: System 1 for analogical reasoning and System 2 for abstract logical reasoning. The framework consists of three modules: the Proposition Generator, Visual-Linguistic Interactor, and Neural-Symbolic Reasoner. The Proposition Generator decomposes complex proposition texts into simple propositions, while the Visual-Linguistic Interactor performs visual-propositions' information interaction. The Neural-Symbolic Reasoner, as System 2, integrates reasoning states and results to obtain the final solution. The proposed method outperforms other baselines in experimental results and verifies the effectiveness of each module through abolition experiments. Case studies demonstrate the method's ability to present inference states and results in the middle step, ensuring interoperability. The researchers suggest that neural symbolic calculation and Divide-and-Conquer strategy can be integrated with Dual-Process Theory to improve compositional reasoning and planning of large language models. The proposed NDCR framework provides a new approach to addressing the challenge of image retrieval from linguistically complex text descriptions.
In DEPLAIN-web, 750 documents were aligned, with 750 documents being aligned manually and the remaining 750 documents being aligned with automatic alignment methods.
The CoNLL++ dataset was created by collecting data from Reuters News from 2020 and annotating them with the same CoNLL-2003 annotation guidelines.

The paper "Prompting PaLM for Translation: Assessing Strategies and Performance" presents a systematic study of large language model prompting for machine translation. The researchers evaluated the transition capability of PaLM, a 540 billion-parameter large language model, using best practices from the machine translation community. They compared PaLM's performance to state-of-the-art systems on the WMT evaluation and used both neural MT metrics and human evaluation results. The study found that the prompting strategy has a significant impact on PaLM's performance, with a 5-shot prompting strategy showing the best results. The researchers also found that the quality of the examples used for prompting is more important than their similarity to the source sentence. The human evaluation results showed that PaLM's fluency is comparable to state-of-the-art systems, but its accuracy is lower due to omission errors. The study concludes that PaLM comes close to commercial systems like Google Translate, but still has some problems with accuracy. The researchers provide recommendations for prompt selection strategies and highlight the importance of selecting high-quality examples for prompting. Overall, the study provides valuable insights into the use of large language models for machine translation and the importance of careful prompting strategies.
Existing works can be broadly classified into four categories, but they either are not applicable to embedding as services or lack transferability.

This presentation introduces ArgAnalysis35K, a large-scale dataset for Argument Quality Analysis. The dataset is unique in its high-quality arguments, diverse range of arguments, and analysis component, which explains why an argument is true. Unlike existing datasets, ArgAnalysis35K is sourced from high-quality tournaments, expert debaters, and novice debaters, providing a more comprehensive understanding of argument quality. The dataset is also diverse, with 24 themes and a wide range of motions.
The analysis component is a key feature of the dataset, representing a combination of claims, premises, and explanations. This component is introduced to the NLP community and allows for a deeper understanding of argument quality. Additionally, the dataset employs instance-based annotator reliability, which captures annotators' biases and eliminates biased judgments on a per-instance basis.
Lastly, the dataset includes a relevance model, which assigns a score to each argument based on its relevance to a particular theme. This model captures the complexity of argument relevance and allows for more accurate scoring. Overall, ArgAnalysis35K provides a comprehensive and reliable dataset for argument quality analysis, offering a unique combination of high-quality arguments, diverse range of arguments, and advanced analysis features. The dataset has the potential to revolutionize the field of argument quality analysis and NLP.

The method addresses the ambiguity of permutations by inducing the alignment as part of the training and using a GPU-friendly continuous relaxation to approximate the highest-scoring permutation, allowing for backpropagation and learning of linguistically more plausible permutations.

The fairness of a downstream NLP model is defined as its ability to perform equally well for all individuals or groups, regardless of their demographic characteristics, social categories, or political leanings, without perpetuating biases or discrimination.

The paper "Minding Language Models’ (Lack of) Theory of Mind: A Plug-and-Play Multi-Character Belief Tracker" investigates the ability of large language models (LLMs) to reason about the mental states of others, a concept known as Theory of Mind (ToM). Traditional ToM tests, such as the Sally-Anne test, involve false-belief questions that require understanding the mental states of multiple characters. LLMs, including ChatGPT and GPT-3, have been shown to perform poorly on these tasks. To address this, the authors propose SymbolicToM, an inference-time method that uses explicit graphical representations to improve ToM reasoning skills in LLMs. The method computes graphical representations of mental states for all combinations of characters and can efficiently answer questions about their beliefs. The authors test SymbolicToM on a range of LLMs and compare its performance to supervised baselines, demonstrating significant gains in accuracy across the board. They also evaluate the method's generalization capabilities on out-of-domain story understanding and linguistic diversity datasets, showing that it outperforms supervised approaches and remains beneficial even in the presence of linguistic variation. The results suggest that SymbolicToM is a promising approach for improving ToM reasoning skills in LLMs.
Myra

This study focuses on the problem of constrained language planning, where abstract goals are decomposed into step-by-step instructions under specific constraints. Unlike previous work that mainly focuses on planning for stereotypical activities, this research aims to plan for goals with multi-faceted constraints. To address this challenge, the authors evaluate and improve the constrained language planning ability of large language models. They extend abstract goals with multi-faceted constraints and acquire specific goals using human-in-the-loop data acquisition with InstructGPT. The results show that large language models achieve unsatisfactory results on planning for specific goals, with low faithfulness to constraints.
To improve the generation quality, the authors adopt the over-generate-then-filter method. They first show constraint types with examples for InstructGPT and obtain specific goals based on seed abstract goals. Then, a filter model is developed to select faithful scripts. The proposed method greatly improves the planning ability of large language models in both semantic completeness and faithfulness to constraints. Furthermore, the authors create a high-quality dataset, CoScript, by distilling constrained language planning datasets from large language models. They demonstrate that smaller models, such as T5 fine-tuned on CoScript, can generate scripts of higher quality than most large language models, indicating that smaller models can surpass larger models when properly trained on suitable datasets.

This presentation introduces the Confidence-guided Adaptive Memory Efficient Optimization (CAME) algorithm, a novel optimizer designed to balance fast convergence and low memory usage in large language model training. Traditional adaptive optimizers like Adam rely on auxiliary memory to store moment estimates, while memory-efficient optimizers like Adafactor incur performance penalties. CAME addresses these limitations by leveraging non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) to reduce memory requirements and introducing a confidence-guided updating mechanism to adaptively handle erroneous updates. The proposed approach calculates the instability between predicted and generated updates, using this residual as a denominator to update the momentum. Experiments on BookCorpus and English Wikipedia demonstrate the effectiveness of CAME, achieving significant improvements in validation accuracy and memory efficiency compared to Adam and Adafactor. CAME also outperforms existing memory-efficient optimizers like SM3 in terms of memory footprint. The results show that CAME achieves comparable performance to the baseline on typical downstream tasks while reducing memory cost, making it a promising solution for large language model training tasks, especially for large batch sizes.

This work proposes a novel framework, RoHT (Reasoning over Hierarchical Question Decomposition Tree), for explainable question answering (XQA). XQA aims to answer questions and provide explanations for the selected answers. Current XQA methods have limitations, including neuro-symbolic methods that rely on structured knowledge bases and decompose-based methods that struggle with diverse natural language. RoHT addresses these challenges by introducing a two-stage framework. Firstly, it builds a Hierarchical Question Decomposition Tree (HQDT) to understand the compositional structure of complex questions. Secondly, it performs probabilistic reasoning over the HQDT to fuse knowledge from knowledge bases and text corpora at different levels. The framework determines the granularity of question decomposition, selects the appropriate knowledge source for each sub-question, and finds the optimal solution among various possible ones. RoHT is evaluated on two challenging complex QA datasets, KQA Pro and Musique, and outperforms existing methods, demonstrating its effectiveness in integrating knowledge from heterogeneous sources and providing explanations for the selected answers. The results show that RoHT can improve the accuracy of XQA and provide a promising direction for future research in this area.

This study investigates the propagation of political biases in language models, from pretraining data to downstream tasks. The researchers propose a pipeline to evaluate the political leaning of language models and examine how they perform on downstream tasks, such as hate speech detection and fake news detection. The study finds that language models exhibit varying political leanings, with GPT-4 being the most liberal. Further pretraining language models on partisan corpora reveals that their ideological coordinates shift accordingly. The study also finds that language models can pick up polarization in society, with models trained on post-2017 data exhibiting more extreme political leanings. When evaluating language models on hate speech and fake news detection, the researchers find that left-leaning models are better at detecting hate speech targeting minority groups, while right-leaning models are better at detecting hate speech targeting more powerful groups. However, this also means that left-leaning models are worse at detecting hate speech targeting more powerful groups, and vice versa. The study highlights a pressing fairness issue regarding language model political leanings and proposes a dilemma between sanitizing political opinions in training data and risking censorship or exclusion.

This paper presents a novel argument for symmetric structures of coordination in English, challenging the widely accepted asymmetric approaches. The authors analyze the principle of dependency length minimization, which states that shorter dependencies are preferred. They demonstrate that this principle can explain the acceptability of sentences with long direct objects and adjuncts, even when they violate the general grammatical principle of direct objects being close to the verb.
The authors also examine statistics from the enhanced Penn Treebank, confirming previous observations that left conjuncts tend to be shorter, particularly when the difference in length between the two conjuncts increases. However, this tendency only occurs when the governor (the head of the coordination) is on the left or absent. When the governor is on the right, the effect disappears.
This finding provides an argument against asymmetric structures of coordination, which single out one conjunct as the head, and in favor of symmetric structures, where all conjuncts are heads. The authors propose that the governor's position influences the preferred length of the conjuncts, supporting the idea that coordination structures are symmetric. The full argument is presented in the paper, and the authors invite discussion at the poster session.

This research, titled "Seen to Unseen: Exploring Compositional Generalization of Multi-Attribute Controllable Dialogue Generation," addresses the limitations of existing controllable dialogue generation methods that focus on single attributes. The authors, Weihao Zeng, Lulu Zhao, and Keqing He, propose a Disentangled Controllable Generation (DCG) model that learns attribute concepts from seen values and uses a disentanglement loss to disentangle different attribute combinations. The DCG model is based on the DialoGPT framework with a compositional prompt module, which includes two types of prompts: attribute-oriented and task-oriented. The authors also introduce a unified reference-free evaluation framework, MAE, for different granularities of attributes. Experiments on two benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of the DCG model and the MAE evaluation metric. The results show that the DCG model outperforms other baselines in attribute controllability and text equality, and that the MAE metric correlates well with human judgments. The authors conclude that their proposed method can disentangle attribute combinations and learn the relations between different attributes, enabling generalization from seen attributes to unseen combinations. This research contributes to the development of more controllable and generalizable dialogue generation models.
